Award.AwardTitle: ADT: Sparse Blind Separation Algorithms of Spectral Mixtures and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Spectral sensing of chemical and biological agents is both a critical area of national security and a vibrant scientific area. Though modern imaging and spectroscopy technology have made it possible to classify pure chemicals by spectra, realistic field data often contain mixtures of chemicals, subject to changing background and environmental noise. In this project, the investigator and his colleagues develop signal processing algorithms and their mathematical analysis for blind separation of spectral mixtures in noisy conditions.
Blind source separation (BSS) methods aim to extract the information of source signals from their mixtures without knowledge of the mixing environment.
A major challenge is that the spectral data are correlated and the conventional ``statistical independence'' fails to be a good separation criterion. Instead, a local spectral sparseness condition weaker than independence will be utilized. The alternative criterion leads to an optimization problem solvable by convex programming. Recent advances in compressive sensing (CS) algorithms are also brought into play. The resulting BSS-CS algorithms are promising for blindly separating more chemicals than the number of spectral measurements. The BSS-CS algorithm will also serve as a preprocessing tool to initialize and improve the convergence of nonconvex optimization methods such as the nonnegative matrix factorization methods for general spectral conditions of chemicals.


Chemicals are often too small to be identified by human eyes. They are captured by sensing equipment in terms of their frequency contents (spectra). Though spectra of pure chemicals can be identified by visual inspection, the spectra of chemical mixtures take a variety of complicated forms and pose a serious challenge for analysis. Chemical mixtures are quite common in the environment. The goal of the project is to develop a new suite of robust separation algorithms for chemical and biological mixtures measured in realistic conditions. A critical issue is to recover the spectra of the individual components of chemical mixtures, and analyze the level of their potential harm and damage. The computation and related technology will be essential for identifying potentially dangerous chemicals released in the environment and for providing valuable information for decision makers to act timely. The investigator and his colleagues shall employ new mathematical techniques and signal processing methods to enhance the computational capability of chemical sensing and identification based on spectral data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spectroscopic sensing is a powerful and a widely used family of techniques for analyzing chemical and biological substances to help threat detection and decision making besides advancing fundamental science. These substances are often not sensible to our five senses. Spectroscopic techniques are designed according to their sensing principles. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) relies on the magnetic properties of the atomistic nucleus to determine the molecular structures. Raman spectroscopy (RS) uses laser light scattering and the resulting energy shift of the laser photons to sense the vibrational modes of a sample.  Hyper-spectral imaging (HSI) makes use of hundreds of contiguous spectral bands to identify nearly invisible objects at subpixel level. Differential optical absorption spectroscopy (DOAS) is based on the light absorption property of matter to identify and analyze atmospheric trace gas concentrations for air quality study.

Because pure substances rarely exist in nature, the observed data from these measurements almost always reflect a mixture of chemicals (source signals). An analogue in daily life is that we often hear a mixture of speech sounds produced by several people at a meeting or a party, yet our brain can focus on one speaker (target source speaker) and extract information there.

In this project, mathematical methods and computational algorithms have been developed to recover the source signals from their mixtures without knowing how they are mixed.

Let A denote the unknown mixing process, S the unknown source signals, X the received data. The general problem is to find both A and S from the relation X = A*S, which has many solutions (under-determined), just like factorizing a composite number (24 = 12*2 = 8*3=6*4 etc). Such a problem is called blind source separation (BSS), where blindness refers to A being unknown. An additional piece of information to pin down the solution is that S as a matrix (a rectangular array of numbers) has many zeros that appear in certain pattern. This is called sparsity. For spectroscopic sensing, S is non-negative (all its entries are non-negative numbers) and sparse in various ways. If each row of S has a peak, and at this peak location, the other rows of S have zero entries, then A can be recovered from columns of X (viewed as data points) geometrically by constructing a minimal cone containing the data points. The remaining non-blind problem is solved by the non-negative least squares method. This is a classical solvable case known in both NMR and HSI literature. However, real world NMR and HSI data often lie outside of this classical regime with S violating the above ideal sparsity assumption. The main outcomes of this project are: (1) identified alternative or generalized solvability conditions involving sparsity of S so that A and S can be computed bits by bits and finally via minimizing a convex function (or convex optimization); (2) improved the results of the classical minimal cone method by deriving reduced equations from the large peak regions of the source signals; (3) recovered A by approximately solving a column selection problem of X under novel metrics that prefer certain sparse row/column patterns of S; (4) developed semi-blind methodology of source recovery when A is partially known; (5) constructed similar sparse BSS methods for mixtures of oscillatory signals such as speech by utilizing sparseness in time domain (pause periods in a speech) and in time-frequency domain; (6) tested and validated the resulting algorithms on data from NMR, HSI, DOAS, RS, and speech recordings in normal room conditions.

 

The intellectual merit of the project findings is the systematic development of algebraic and geometric methods to solve under-determined matrix factorization problems based on sparseness patterns of the source signals...
